entry.title: Commitment anxiety
entry.body: I keep hesitating to finish a small project because I worry it will prove I'm not as good as I think.

outputs.editor:
SUMMARY:
You hesitate to finish a small project because you fear it will reveal you are less capable.
FIXES:
- "keep hesitating": specify the behavior (delaying starts, avoiding deadlines).
- "finish a small project": name the project to make the scope concrete.
- "prove I'm not as good": clarify what standard of "good" you mean.
REWRITE:
I keep hesitating to finish a small project because I worry completing it will reveal I'm less capable than I think.
outputs.definer:
KEY TERMS:
- "hesitating": delaying a decision to finish for more than a week after planning to do so.
- "small project": a task expected to take one week or less to complete.
AMBIGUITIES:
- "not as good": could mean lower skill than peers or lower skill than your own standard.
- "keep": could mean weekly or only occasionally.
BOUNDARIES:
- Not claiming: you are actually less capable.
- Not claiming: the project is objectively difficult.
outputs.skeptic:
CORE CLAIM:
You delay finishing because you fear the project will expose lower ability.
CHALLENGES:
- "keep hesitating": this could reflect unclear scope rather than fear, which changes the intervention.
- "small project": if it is ill-defined, the delay may be due to missing requirements, not self-doubt.
- "prove I'm not as good": you may be using fear as a story when the real issue is low priority.
TEST:
Set a 60-minute timer and complete a concrete deliverable for this project once this week.
outputs.coach:
INTENT:
You want to finish the project without the fear of being exposed ("prove I'm not as good").
OPTIONS:
- Finish a single concrete deliverable in 7 days, risking a visible result. Done looks like one shipped artifact.
- Decide to pause the project for 7 days, risking no progress. Done looks like no work on it for a week.
- Cut the scope to a one-page version and ship it, risking incompleteness. Done looks like a published draft.
RECOMMENDATION:
Choose the cut-scope version because it forces completion without pretending the fear is gone. It closes the option of endless tweaking for the next 7 days.
FOR THE NEXT 7 DAYS, STOP:
- Renaming or reorganizing the project
- Adding new requirements
